posts.cooked:
Hello,

We are using a Profiled PID controller to control a robotic arm. We noticed the arm moved too slowly so we gradually increased the max velocity and acceleration from 3 and 3 up to 10 and 10 rotations, respectively. However, we noticed no change in speed. Is this the proper way to increase the speed of the arm or should we try something else? Should we increase the speed even more? I left the line of code where we declare the ProfiledPIDController and TrapezoidProfile constraints. Thank you in advance!

posts.name: Jainish Patel
posts.cooked: Hello. One thing I can think of about this problem is the gear ratio of the arm. If the arm has a high gear ratio the initial driving gear has to spin a lot of times to perform one rotation of the final driven gear. I suggest try increasing the velocity and acceleration constraints until you do notice it going faster.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
What are the units of all these values?

Acceleration is measured in velocity units per second, so if you make these values equivalent, then it will take 1 full second to fully accelerate to your cruise velocity and 1 full second to decelerate. Normally I like to have the acceleration be much faster, (this is something you have to measure), but I tend to imagine that the robot arm can accelerate to full speed in at most a quarter of a second if its geared properly. This means ACCEL_MAX should be 4*VELO_MAX.

But again, I’m wondering what the units of these values are. Is it rotations of the arm? Rotations of the motor? Can we also see the code you have to take the output of the controller and pass it to the motor?
The gear ratio of 280:1. 280 rotations of the motor to rotate the arm 1 rotation. We’ll try your strategy first.
Units: rotations of the arm Here is the code that raises the arm. This method is called continuously while a button is pressed.

posts.name: Jainish Patel
posts.cooked: It make sense why the arm behaves slow. For reference our arm is 165:1 and our velocity and acceleration constraints are 94.7 and 108 respectively.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
Right, but what I want to see is the code that actually commands the motor. This just sets the pid goal, but at some point you need to take the output of the pid and pass it to the motor. I assume this is in your periodic() method.

Also, if you JUST control your arm with “increaseGoal”, then the velocity wont matter. The “velocity” of the device will be entirely dependent on how fast increaseGoal triggers, which will be 50 times a second. In this case, you’re increasing the goal by 12.5 degrees per second.

Now, if theres a different command which sets the goal of the arm to the setpoint immediately, then that will depend on your velocity and acceleration profile.

My bad. I think this is what you want. The right motor is set to follow the left motor.

Also, yes, you are correct. Velocity only matters when it comes to setpoints.

posts.name: loafdog
posts.cooked: How your PID is tuned also matters.  Before you try to use ProfiledPIDController and constraints, can you run your arm with plain PID and get the movement speed you want? Or maybe use the ProfiledPIDController but try adjust PID values(probably P) to increase speed.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
If the units are in rotations of the arm itself, then 10 or even 3 rotations per second is VERY fast.

This code looks correct which sets the output though. Maybe you could consider putting the setpoint position, setpoint velocity, real position, real velocity, and output volts to smart dashboard and graphing that over time?

If the profiledPIDcontroller is doing its job, you should see the output tracking the setpoints very closely. If you see that the setpoints are running away from the actual position/velocity, it means the PID and feed-forward part of the controller isn’t doing its job.
